Dear Mr. Hawkins:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
February 24, 2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the
contract and Modified Implementation Sustainability and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements,
a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any
licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4166 Discharge plan.
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care, all
of the following information shall be documented in the
case record within 14 days after discharge:
(a) The date of and reason for discharge, and the new
location of the child.
(b) A brief summary or other documentation of the
services provided while in residence, including medical and
dental services.
(c) An assessment of the resident’s needs that remain to
be met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the facility after
discharge.
(e) A statement that the discharge plan
recommendations, including medical and dental follow up
that is needed, have been reviewed with the resident and
with the parent and with the responsible case manager.
(f) The name and official title of the person to whom the
resident was discharged.
Two of two closed residential youth files reviewed lacked the required discharge plan
information in subsections (a) through (f).
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional ISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract/Policy violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements
except for the following:
1

RFCAN Contractor Responsibilities- Services to be Provided-
2.10.R Wardrobe/ Personal Possessions
The Contractor must assure that each youth has an
adequate wardrobe as defined by and documented on the
Clothing Inventory Checklist (DHS3377) while in placement
and upon leaving placement. When the youth is absent or
at the conclusion of the placement, the Contractor must
have a process in place to keep the youth’s wardrobe and
possessions safe until claimed by the youth or primary
caseworker/agency. If the possessions are not claimed
within 90 calendar days, the Contractor may dispose of the
items at its discretion.
Three of three open residential youth files reviewed did not have the required
Clothing Inventory Checklist (DHS 3377). One file did include a checklist that was
not fully completed or dated. Two of two closed residential youth files reviewed did
not have the required Clothing Inventory Checklist (DHS 3377) upon leaving
placement.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
- All documentation of required training completed by employees should be in the
employee personal file, for example the shadow shifts for new employees. The
facility had this information, but it was not included in the personnel filed provided
to the consultant at the time of the review.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
- The increased number of restraints were discussed. The restraints have been
noted to be less than a minute hold because the youth will drop their body weight
to the floor. The Chief Administrator noted the facility is working closely with the
AEGIS institute in how to best support training staff members. The facility is
meeting as a team to review all restraints that occur on a weekly basis. The
facility is also working with Residential Collaboration and Technical Assistance
Unit (RCTAU).
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The facility had fifteen special investigations during this period under review with eight
resulting in corrective action plans. The non-compliances included behavior
management, discipline, staff qualifications, and agency polices. The facility’s
2

corrective action plan compliance is monitored quarterly and have completed all
current corrective action plans.
Chief Administrator Assessment:
Chief Administrator noted over this reporting period COVID-19 has continued to be a
significant factor in the provision of services. Most notably they have seen an
increase in resignations and a very challenging hiring environment. The facility has
increased their training for new staff and have brought on a new Staff Coach to work
alongside new staff to help ensure that they have everything they need to be
successful. The facility continues to work on reducing and eventually eliminating
restraints.
Interviews:
Staff and youth interviews were conducted during the inspection and no issues or
concerns were raised. The youth all reported feeling safe and had positive
relationships with staff members. The staff all reported feeling supported by direct
supervisors as well as administration. The facility has implemented a new de-
escalation model, AEGIS and this supports the facility to be more trauma informed.
The facility has created “calming room” in the homes for the youth that live there.
These are spaces where youth can go when they need help to regulate themselves
with sensory items.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on their regular license.
